Award.AwardTitle: Estimation and Inference in Nonlinear Models with Multidimensional Heterogeneity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will develop new statistical tools to analyze relationships between economic variables using models with multiple sources of unobserved heterogeneity. Accounting for such rich heterogeneity is important in economic applications because the relationships between variables are expected to be heterogeneous even among individuals with the same observable characteristics. For example, two individuals with the same age, gender, and race can experience very different returns to high school graduation on earnings. The investigator will analyze nonlinear models with multidimensional latent or unobservable variables, which allow for rich patterns of observed and unobserved heterogeneity. They include binary and other limited response models with random coefficients and/or factor error structure. The objects of interest in these models are often summary measures of the heterogeneous effects such as averages or quantiles.

Nonlinear models with multidimensional heterogeneity pose theoretical and practical challenges such as the choice and computation of the effects to report, and the quantification of the sampling uncertainty associated with the estimated effects. This project aims to tackle all these challenges for an important class of models estimated from cross sectional and panel data. More specifically, the project will address: (1) summarizing and reporting effects in nonlinear models with multidimensional heterogeneity, (2) developing the statistical properties of distribution regression as a flexible tool to model, estimate and make inference on quantile effects of continuous and discrete responses in cross sectional and panel data applications, (3) deriving bias corrections for fixed effects estimators of limited response panel models with factor error structure, and (4) identification of binary response models with multidimensional heterogeneity. The methods proposed will be illustrated with several empirical applications from labor economics, health economics, and international trade.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has developed statistical tools to analyze relationships between economic variables using rich models that allow for multiple forms of individual heterogeneity. More specifically, it has developed estimation and inference methods for cross section and panel nonlinear models with multidimensional unobservable variables. These include nonseparable models and limited dependent variable models with factor error structure that are commonly used in economics and other fields. The project has dealt with practical issues such as how to summarize and report heterogeneous effects in nonlinear models, or how to construct confidence bands for quantile effects from confidence bands for distributions; as well as more theoretical issues such as developing the statistical properties of distribution regression as a flexible tool to model and estimate quantile effects, or deriving bias corrections for fixed effects estimators of nonlinear panel factor models.  The methods proposed have been applied to the analysis of heterogeneity in the gender wage gap, impact of insurance coverage on health care utilization, determinants of international trade, and effect of democracy on economic growth.

The following papers have been completed and either published in scientific journals or presented at major conferences:

- The Sorted Effects Method: Discovering Heterogenous Effects Beyond Their
Averages, joint with Victor Chernozhukov and Ye Luo, Econometrica 86(6).

- Nonseparable Multinomial Choice Models in Cross-Section and Panel Data,
with Victor Chernozhukov and Whitney Newey, Journal of Econometrics 211.

- Fixed Effects Estimation of Large T Panel Data Models, with Martin Weidner,
Annual Review of Economics 10.

- Mastering Panel 'Metrics: Causal Impact of Democracy on Growth, with
Shuowen Chen and Victor Chernozhukov, American Economic Review Papers and Proceedings 109.

 - Generic Inference on Quantile and Quantile Effect Functions for Discrete
Outcomes, with Victor Chernozhukov, Blaise Melly and Kaspar Wuthrich,
forthcoming at the Journal of the American Statistical Association.

- Nonlinear Factor Models for Network and Panel Data, with Mingli Chen and
Martin Weidner, conditionally accepted at the Journal of Econometrics.

- Network and panel quantile effects via distribution regression, with Victor
Chernozhukov and Martin Weidner, arXiv:1803.08154.

- Distribution Regression with Sample Selection, with an Application to Wage
Decompositions in the UK, with Victor Chernozhukov and Siyi Luo,
arXiv:1811.11603.

- Generic Machine Learning Inference on Heterogenous Treatment Effects in
Randomized Experiments, with Victor Chernozhukov, Mert Demirer and Esther Duflo, arXiv:1712.04802.

- Shape-Enforcing Operators for Point and Interval Estimators, with Xi Chen,
Victor Chernozhukov, Scott Kostyshak and Ye Luo, arXiv:1809.01038.

The PI has also developed software in R:

- SortedEffects: Estimation and Inference Methods for Sorted Causal Effects and Classification Analysis, joint with Shuowen Chen, Victor Chernozhukov and Ye Luo. Available at the R project and PI web sites.

- discreteQ: Generic Inference on Quantile and Quantile Effect Functions for Discrete Outcomes, joint with Victor Chernozhukov, Blaise Melly and Kaspar Wuthrich. Available at the Github and PI web sites.
